title: 107_s1868
content:
The Act is titled the "National Child Protection and Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to define a "qualified State program" as policies and procedures required to implement the Act, including timeframes for background checks, fee limits for State checks, authorized agencies for background check requests, and qualified entities for submitting requests. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to specify the qualified entities responsible for submitting background check requests to authorized agencies. The term "routinely" is defined as instances where a high percentage of nationwide background check requests are returned within specific timeframes. SEC. 3. STRENGTHENING AND ENFORCING THE NATIONAL CHILD PROTECTION ACT AND THE VOLUNTEERS FOR CHILDREN ACT. Section 3 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for providers caring for children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for providers caring for children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. Response time for inquiries to the Attorney General is set at 15 business days. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow qualified entities in states without programs to request national criminal background checks from the Attorney General. Response time for requests is set at 20 business days. Additionally, subsection (b) is modified to give the Attorney General discretion in making decisions. In subsection (b), changes allow the Attorney General to decide on requests for national criminal background checks. Qualified entities can now request checks from a State authorized agency as well. SEC. 4. DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION.

The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow the Attorney General and authorized State agencies to share criminal history background check records with qualified entities. 

SEC. 7. OFFICE FOR VOLUNTEER AND PROVIDER SCREENING.

The Attorney General will establish an Office for Volunteer and Provider Screening to facilitate national criminal background checks for qualified entities. Model guidelines will be provided to assist in making fitness determinations for care providers based on their criminal history records. SEC. 5. FEES.

Amends the National Child Protection Act of 1993 regarding fees for national criminal fingerprint background checks. Limits fees to $5 for volunteers and $18 for providers with qualified entities.

SEC. 6. STRENGTHENING STATE FINGERPRINT TECHNOLOGY. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology, providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. Additional funds will be given to each State to hire personnel for training county law enforcement agencies on inputting criminal data into the national background check system. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 authorizes funding for states with qualified programs to input criminal and disposition data into the national background check system. States can receive up to $2,000,000 for this purpose. Appropriations are authorized to improve fingerprint technology and hire data entry personnel in each state and the District of Columbia from 2004 to 2008. SEC. 7. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Information from national criminal fingerprint background checks cannot be altered except for national security reasons. Qualified entities must assign a representative to handle requested information and delete unnecessary details. Releasing this information to unauthorized individuals carries criminal penalties. Unauthorized disclosure of information from national criminal fingerprint background checks can result in a $50,000 fine or up to 1 year in prison. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Funds remain available until expended.
